I want a way to switch between two tabs, one tab beings store hours and another tab being monthly events
1 / 1

Sure! You can use Bootstrap's tab functionality to create two tabs that switch between displaying store hours and monthly events.

First, you'll need to add the tab structure to your HTML:

php
<ul class="nav nav-tabs">
  <li class="nav-item">
    <a class="nav-link active" data-toggle="tab" href="#store-hours">Store Hours</a>
  </li>
  <li class="nav-item">
    <a class="nav-link" data-toggle="tab" href="#monthly-events">Monthly Events</a>
  </li>
</ul>

<div class="tab-content">
  <div class="tab-pane fade show active" id="store-hours">
    <!-- Store hours table goes here -->
  </div>
  <div class="tab-pane fade" id="monthly-events">
    <!-- Monthly events go here -->
  </div>
</div>

Then, you'll need to add the necessary JavaScript to activate the tab functionality:

javascript
$(document).ready(function(){
  $('a[data-toggle="tab"]').on('shown.bs.tab', function (e) {
    var target = $(e.target).attr("href"); // activated tab
    if(target == "#monthly-events") {
      // Code to show monthly events
    }
  });
});

In this example, we're using jQuery to listen for when a tab is shown and then checking the target of that tab. If the target is the monthly events tab, we can run some code to display the monthly events.

You can customize this code to suit your needs, such as adding additional tabs or changing the behavior of the tabs when they are clicked.

1 / 1
What might the rest of the javascript code look like?
1 / 1

Here's an example of how you could implement tab switching using JavaScript:

js
// Select the tabs and tab panes
const tabs = document.querySelectorAll('.nav-link');
const tabPanes = document.querySelectorAll('.tab-pane');

// Add a click event listener to each tab
tabs.forEach(tab => {
  tab.addEventListener('click', e => {
    e.preventDefault();

    // Remove the active class from all tabs and tab panes
    tabs.forEach(tab => tab.classList.remove('active'));
    tabPanes.forEach(pane => pane.classList.remove('active', 'show'));

    // Add the active class to the clicked tab and its associated pane
    const selectedTab = e.target;
    const selectedPane = document.querySelector(selectedTab.getAttribute('href'));
    selectedTab.classList.add('active');
    selectedPane.classList.add('active', 'show');
  });
});

This code selects all the tab links and tab panes and adds a click event listener to each tab link. When a tab is clicked, it removes the "active" class from all the tabs and panes, then adds the "active" class to the clicked tab and its associated pane. This effectively switches between the two tabs. You can customize the selectors to match your HTML structure.

I only want the vertical lines black
1 / 1

To only make the vertical lines of the table black, you can use the border-right property in CSS. Here's an example:

css
table {
  border-collapse: collapse;
}

th,
td {
  border-bottom: 1px solid black;
  border-right: 1px solid black;
}

th {
  background-color: #f2f2f2;
}

In this example, the border-right property is applied to both th and td elements to make the vertical lines black. The border-bottom property is used to make the horizontal lines black. The border-collapse property is set to collapse to remove the default space between table cells. Finally, the background-color property is applied to th elements to give them a gray background.

1 / 1
I meant I only want to make the horizontal lines black
1 / 1

To make only the horizontal lines of the table black, you can use the following CSS code:

css
table {
  border-collapse: collapse;
}

table td, table th {
  border-bottom: 1px solid black;
}

table th {
  border-top: 1px solid black;
}

This will collapse the table borders and apply a black bottom border to all table cells and a black top border to table headers. This way, only the horizontal lines will be black.

You can adjust the value of the border-radius property to achieve the desired amount of rounding. Keep in mind that some browsers may require vendor prefixes for these properties, such as -webkit-border-top-right-radius, -moz-border-radius-topright, etc.

Sure! Here's how you can convert that JavaScript code to a script tag:

php
<script>
  const carousel = document.querySelector('.carousel');
  const carouselInner = carousel.querySelector('.carousel-inner');

  var imageUrls = [
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_2.jpeg",
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_3.jpeg",
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_4.jpeg",
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_5.jpeg",
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_6.jpeg",
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_7.jpeg",
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_8.jpeg",
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_9.jpeg",
    "Assets/LAS_Plant_10.jpeg",
  ];

  // Load each image into the carousel
  imageUrls.forEach((url, index) => {
    // Create a new carousel item
    const carouselItem = document.createElement('div');
    carouselItem.classList.add('carousel-item');
  
    // Create a new image element
    const img = document.createElement('img');
    img.src = url;
    img.classList.add('d-block', 'w-100', 'carousel-img', 'flex-img');
    img.alt = 'Slide ' + index;
  
    // Add the image to the carousel item and the carousel item to the carousel
    carouselItem.appendChild(img);

    carouselInner.appendChild(carouselItem);
  });
</script>

Just make sure to add this script tag after the HTML element it references.
